questions.question: Question 1: What is the first investigation you would advise to a patient with a large thyroid swelling?
questions.explanation:
Assessing the biochemical function of the thyroid i.e. thyroid function test (TFT) is the first 
investigation done in any thyroid condition. Assessment of TSH, T3, and T4 is done. However, TSH is most helpful in determining the 
management plan, especially in patients with thyroid nodules who clinically appear to be 310 
Sold by @itachibot euthyroid. Modalities for evaluation of thyroid swelling include: • Laboratory evaluation • TSH • T3 • T4 • Thyroid imaging • Ultrasound • Radioisotope scanning • CT/MRI • Biopsy techniques • Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) • Tru-cut/core-needle biopsy

questions.question:

swallowing. TSH, T3, and T4 levels are normal. An ultrasound reports the swelling to be 
cystic and regular with low suspicion for malignancy. What is the next step in the 
management of this patient?

options.a: Perform an fine needle aspiration biopsy
options.d: Reassure the patient and monitor periodically

questions.explanation:

questions.question: Question 3: FNAC is useful in all types of thyroid cancers except
questions.explanation:
FNAC is not useful in the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma of thyroid as it cannot differentiate 
between benign and malignant follicular lesion. Trucut biopsy is used to differentiate between 
them as follicular thyroid malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Limitations of FNAC in thyroid disorders: • Cannot distinguish between follicular carcinoma and adenoma • Cannot distinguish between Hurthle cell carcinoma and adenoma • Not useful in Reidel’s thyroiditis

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient regions?
questions.explanation:
Follicular thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient areas. Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-sufficient areas, 
children, and radiation-exposed areas.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient presented with a thyroid nodule. The USG showed an irregular hypoechoic mass 
with microcalcifications. Lymph nodes were not involved. FNAC showed a follicular neoplasm 
with predominantly Hurthle cells. Intra-op frozen section confirms capsular invasion. What is 
the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hurthle cell follicular carcinoma. The most appropriate 
management is total thyroidectomy with prophylactic central neck dissection. Hurthle cell 
carcinoma is a variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma. As compared to follicular thyroid cancer, it has a poorer prognosis as it is more likely to 
metastasize. It is often bilateral and multifocal. The histological picture consists of predominantly 
oxyphil (Hurthle, Askanazy) cells containing abundant mitochondria. It cannot be diagnosed 
solely by FNAC as these cancers are characterized by vascular & capsular invasion. Surgical management of Hurthle cell carcinoma: Extent of cancer

Question 10: A 32-year-old woman came to the surgeon with a thyroid swelling that had developed a year 
ago. On examination, the swelling was 3 cm in size, firm and immobile. Further, 
lymphadenopathy was present. A biopsy of the swelling is given below. Which of the following

Question 11: 304 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following describes lateral aberrant thyroid?

options.a: Defective development of the fourth pharyngeal pouch
options.b: Metastatic thyroid cancer in lymph nodes
options.d: Cystic swelling of the thyroglossal duct

questions.explanation:
Lateral aberrant thyroid almost always represents metastatic thyroid cancer in lymph nodes. Thyroid tissue situated lateral to the carotid sheath and jugular vein found along the course of the 
thyroglossal duct was previously termed lateral aberrant thyroid. It is associated with papillary 
thyroid cancer in the ipsilateral thyroid lobe. The image given below shows the lateral aberrant thyroid.

questions.question: Question 12: Which type of thyroid cancer has the best prognosis?
questions.explanation:
318 
Sold by @itachibot Patients with papillary thyroid carcinoma have an excellent prognosis with a >95% 10-year 
survival rate.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 45-year-old man came to the surgery OPD with a midline neck swelling. He does not have 
any other complaints. The patient had received chemoradiation for Hodgkin’s lymphoma 
nearly 20 years ago. On palpation, the mass is about 3 cm in size, non-tender, hard, fixed, 
and seems to arise from the right lobe of the thyroid. TSH levels were raised. A radioiodine 
uptake study showed cold nodule. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The history of radiation therapy to the head and neck for Hodkin's lymphoma and a cold nodule 
on radioiodine uptake scan are suggestive of papillary thyroid cancer. Radiation exposure is an identifiable aetiological factor in the development of differentiated 
thyroid cancer (follicular and papillary thyroid cancer). The most important factor, however, is 
irradiation of the thyroid before 5 years of age. Thyroid lymphomas are non-Hodgkin’s B-cell lymphomas. They present with B-symptoms like 
fever, night sweats, and weight loss in addition to neck swelling. Thus, thyroid lymphoma is an 
unlikely diagnosis. Thyroid lymphomas often develop in the setting of lymphocytic infiltration.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 45-year-old patient presents with diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland. Laboratory 
studies reveal low T3, T4, high TSH and the presence of anti-TPO antibodies. FNAC from the 
gland shows enlarged cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Which of the following 
malignancies is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical case scenario is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphoma or 
malignant lymphoma is associated with long-standing Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphomas are usually non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas, often associated with long-standing 
Hashimoto’s thyroiditis (autoimmune lymphocytic thyroiditis). The clinical features include: B - symptoms i.e. fever, night sweats, and weight loss As FNAC cannot characterize lymphoma, Tru-Cut biopsy is preferred. Chemotherapy and 
radiation therapy are often sufficient. Total thyroidectomy is indicated only in residual/recurrent 
disease. A chemotherapy regimen (RCHOP) is the first line of management. R - Rituximab C - Cyclophosphamide H - Hydroxydaunorubicin (Adriamycin) O - Oncovin (Vincristine) P - Prednisolone

questions.question:
Question 15: A 72-year-old woman has a history of papillary thyroid carcinoma left untreated for 2 years. 
She complains that the rapid enlargement in her neck swelling over the last month has made 
it difficult for her to swallow and talk. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.a: Local invasion of the surrounding structures

questions.explanation:
An elderly woman with rapidly enlarging neck mass and dysphagia in the setting of an untreated 
papillary carcinoma suggests a diagnosis of anaplastic thyroid cancer. Anaplastic thyroid cancer, a poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma, is the most aggressive cancer 
and has the worst prognosis of all thyroid malignancies. 319 
Sold by @itachibot It usually occurs in elderly females. The typical manifestation is an with rapidly enlarging neck 
mass, dysphagia, and cervical tenderness. Patients usually have a history of untreated 
differentiated thyroid carcinoma (DTC). Local invasion to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) 
causes hoarseness. It may also cause tracheal obstruction. Distant metastasis is more common in 
the lungs via the hematogenous route. Diagnosis is made by FNAC. However, trucut/open biopsy is frequently used to confirm the 
diagnosis in cases of doubt. Management: • If metastasis is absent: Total thyroidectomy + LN dissection • If metastasis is present: Palliative care with chemotherapy and radiotherapy • If tracheal obstruction: Isthmectomy to relieve obstruction

questions.question:
Question 16: A 34-year-old woman was brought in a dehydrated state and complains of loose stools. On 
examination, a tender neck swelling was found which was found to be present for 1 year. 
Histopathology of the swelling shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Histopathology 
shows the presence of amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland. They are 
derived from the neural crest cells of the ultimobranchial bodies. Most of the MTCs occur sporadically. However, around a quarter of the cancers are associated 
with familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B. Patients with sporadic MTC present at an older age, whereas patients with familial MTC usually 
present at a younger age. Features of MTC include: • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy • Dysphagia, dysphonia or dyspnea if locally invaded • Diarrhoea due to increased intestinal motility by serotonin • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production • Metastasis is blood-borne • Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid 
stroma It is diagnosed by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin, CEA levels, and 
fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass. Total thyroidectomy with central neck node dissection is the treatment of choice in MTC patients. 
External beam radiotherapy can be used in patients with unresectable tumors. Targeted therapy 
can be considered using vandetanib, sorafenib, sunitinib, and cabozantinib. Prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutation 
and within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation. 320 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: Choose the substances secreted by medullary thyroid carcinoma:
questions.explanation:
Medullary thyroid tumors secrete calcitonin, serotonin, histaminadases, and CEA 
(carcinoembryonic antigen).

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient with medullary thyroid carcinoma is posted for surgery. He is nearly 6.5 ft tall, with 
a slender build and elongated digits. What is the screening test that should be done 
pre-operatively?
questions.explanation:
This patient with medullary thyroid carcinoma and features of marfanoid habitus (very tall patient 
with long, slender fingers and toes) is suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome. Such patients are to be 
screened for pheochromocytoma by measuring urinary catecholamines. Pheochromocytoma, if present, should be treated first, and then MTC is to be treated next. A thyroid swelling with elevated calcitonin indicates a medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTC 
can either be sporadic (80%) or familial (RET gene mutation). In case of familial medullary 
thyroid carcinoma, stimulation with pentagastrin increases the release of calcitonin. This can be 
used for the screening of medullary thyroid carcinoma. MTC can be inherited as a part of autosomal dominant (AD) syndromes such as: • Familial MTC • MEN 2A • MEN 2B Prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutation 
and within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation. Note: Serum calcium is measured to screen for parathyroid adenoma in MEN 2A.

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient is diagnosed with medullary thyroid carcinoma. Which of the following could be 
used to screen the rest of her family?
questions.explanation:
Screening of patients with familial MTC was historically done using pentagastrin stimulation test 
for calcitonin levels to make the diagnosis. Pentagastrin is a synthetic gastrin analogue. It acts on the CCK-B/gastrin receptor of the C 
cells and increases the basal rate of calcitonin secretion. Basal calcitonin level = total C cell mass x rate of secretion. Medullary thyroid tumors secrete calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), but also other 
peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide, histaminadases, prostaglandins E2 and F2, and 
serotonin. Another test that can be used for screening is calcium-stimulated calcitonin levels.

questions.question: Question 21: Prophylactic thyroidectomy is indicated in patients with which of the following features:

options.b: Marfanoid habitus, multiple neuromas on the lip and familial pheochromocytoma,
options.c: Dense lymphatic infiltration of the thyroid detected on FNAC

questions.explanation:
Prophylactic thyroidectomy is indicated in MEN 2B syndrome as they can develop medullary 
thyroid carcinoma. This syndrome manifests as: • Pheochromocytoma • Marfanoid habitus • Mucosal neuromas • Medullary thyroid cancer. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) can be inherited as familial MTC, MEN 2A or MEN 2B 
syndromes. These conditions are autosomal dominant and occur due to RET proto-oncogene 
mutation. As almost all cases of MEN 2B develop medullary thyroid cancer, a prophylactic 
thyroidectomy may be performed even during infancy. Option A: The most common malignancy in thyroglossal cysts is papillary thyroid carcinoma. In 
such a case, Sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is considered. Option C: Hashimoto's thyroiditis shows dense lymphatic infiltration of the thyroid detected on 
FNAC which is treated with thyroxine. However, total thyroidectomy is performed in malignant 
transformation to thyroid lymphoma. Option D: Upregulation of BRAF is associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 23: Which of the following statements is false about the 8th edition AJCC staging of thyroid 
neoplasms?

options.a: In DTC, distant metastasis is IVB
options.b: In staging, age barrier is 55 years
options.d: N1a includes level VI and VII

questions.explanation:
Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the 
definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage. Differentiated Thyroid Cancer: • The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis. • N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 
disease is stage I. If  55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II. • T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland • T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into 
strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles) • Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as 
central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII 
presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers. • In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is 
classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancer 
continues to be classified as IVC disease. Minimal or occult/microcarcinoma are tumors 1 cm or less in size. They have no evidence of local 
invasiveness through the thyroid capsule or angioinvasion. Occult malignancies are usually not 
associated with lymph node metastases. However, about 25% of patients with these tumors have 
associated occult lymph node metastases. These are nonpalpable and are found incidentally at 
operative and histologic examinations or at autopsy. Anaplastic : • Unlike previous editions where all anaplastic thyroid cancers were classified as T4 disease, 
anaplastic cancers now use the same T definitions as differentiated thyroid cancer. • Intrathyroidal disease (T1-3a) is stage IVA • Gross extrathyroidal extension(T3b,T4) or cervical lymph node metastases (N1) is stage IVB • Distant metastases (M1) are stage IVC 323

questions.question:
Question 24: Which of the following will not be a treatment option for a pregnant patient with papillary 
thyroid carcinoma?

options.b: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection

questions.explanation:
Radioiodine ablation of thyroid is contraindicated in pregnant women due to risk of radiation 
exposure to the fetus. Therapeutic uses for radioactive iodine • In primary thyrotoxicosis after 45 years. • In autonomous toxic nodule after 45 years, it is useful as remaining gland still will function 
adequately after radiotherapy. 325 
Sold by @itachibot • In follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere in 
the body, as in bones or lungs, then I131 is given.

questions.question:
Question 25: A patient with papillary thyroid carcinoma underwent total thyroidectomy with central neck 
dissection, a month ago. At present, a whole-body iodine scan is positive. What is the next 
step in management?
questions.explanation:
Radio-iodine ablation is undertaken when a whole-body iodine scan is positive after a total 
thyroidectomy for any differentiated thyroid cancer (papillary or follicular carcinoma). The presence of any metastatic or residual thyroid tissue after total thyroidectomy can be detected 
by observing the uptake of radio-iodine in the entire body. To achieve effective uptake of 
radio-iodine, TSH levels need to be greatly increased, for example, by withdrawing thyroxine after 
the surgery for 4-6 weeks. A positive whole-body iodine scan after total thyroidectomy indicates that there is either a 
metastatic or residual disease present. These patients are treated with I131 for radio-iodine 
ablation. A negative scan means there is no metastasis or residual thyroid tissue. They are followed up 
regularly with serum thyroglobulin, TSH and USG-neck. If the tumour is resistant to radioiodine ablation, EBRT (external beam radiotherapy) is done.

questions.question: Question 26: A whole-body iodine scan is not useful in patients with which thyroid malignancy?
questions.explanation:
After a total thyroidectomy, a whole-body iodine scan is not useful for detecting residual thyroid 
tissue or metastasis in medullary thyroid carcinoma. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumour of parafollicular or C cells. These cells which are derived 
from neural crest cells, do not take up iodine. A whole-body iodine scan is useful in thyroid tumours derived from follicular cells that take up 
iodine.

questions.question:
Question 27: Which of the following scales consider the completeness of surgical resection to determine the 
prognosis of a patient with thyroid cancer?
questions.explanation:
MACIS scale includes completeness of the original surgical resection to determine the prognosis 
of the thyroid cancer. Prognostic indicators of well differentiated thyroid cancers: • AGES system - Age, histologic Grade, Extrathyroidal invasion, and metastases and tumor Size. • AMES system - Age (men <40 years old, women <50 years old), Metastases, Extrathyroidal 
spread, and Size of tumors (< or >5 cm). • DAMES - DNA aneuploidy + AMES • GAMES - Grade + AMES • TNM staging - Tumor, Nodal status, Metastases. 326 
Sold by @itachibot • MACIS scale (postop modification) - distant Metastases, Age at presentation (<40 or >40 
years old), Completeness of original surgical resection, extrathyroidal Invasion, and Size of 
original lesion (in centimeters). 327 
Sold by @itachibot The Parathyroids
